The game concept is very simple: loot a bunch of cool stuff, build your loadout and shred zombies with it. Then, after collecting enough gas, you can extract from the current stage and go on to the next stage. After 7 stages you fight the final boss and after defeating it, you have completed your first run. Back in your camp, there is some meta progression to unlock and then you start all over again.

Despite the base game mechanics being very simple, each run is still a fun and more or less unique experience (more on that later). The complexity comes from the different items, weapons and characters and the way you combine them. Managing your inventory, choosing which items to equip, which to sell and building your loadout is really cool. I really like how items are affected by your inventory arrangement, in particular. This can all lead to some pretty insane loadout configurations. And testing those against hordes of zombies is REALLY fun.

However, there are also some aspects that are still in need of improvement. First of all, the game needs a lot more content. There is already an okay amount in the game, but it's stretched very thin and restricted by a lot of meta progression upgrades. It took me about 45 hours (including the 10h I spent on the demo) to unlock all content (damn the astronaut). Looking back now, it feels like the time I've spent on the game and the amount of content I unlocked during that time don't really add up. The balance just seems a little off and there were some times, when I just rushed through another run to get duct tape for an upgrade, so that I could finally get more items for more complex builds.
All of that just felt a little dry and unrewarding [u] sometimes[/u] . Especially because you can only get a maximum amount of 2 duct tape in one run and therefore have to defeat the boss, if you want to progress. This can be a little frustrating, because it takes away your motivation to experiment with new loadouts and higher danger levels. You have to play it safe and always get the 2 possible duct tape to ensure your progress.
That also leads to my last point of criticism. Currently, endgame is a very dull experience. After finishing a couple of runs, you pretty much get the hang of it and defeating the boss isn't really much of a challenge anymore. What keeps the game interesting is honing your loadout to perfection by getting every last backpack space filled with the best possible item to boost your weapon and then see how far you can get with that. And this is all possible by staying in one stage for as long as you can last or by choosing the endless mode after completing a run. But there are some problems you'll run into.
For starters you get no meta progression in endless mode, which makes it kind of pointless, if you haven't unlocked everything yet. Also, as I mentioned earlier, there is not enough content in the game yet, so endless mode gets repetitive really quickly (more than in other similar games). And finally, you come across perfomance issues rather quickly, especially with some specific weapons and builds. Some of those perfomance issues have already been patched but not all of them. To be fair, it was highlighted by the devs that endless mode is still a work in progress and more of a fun bonus. Nevertheless, it plays a big part in keeping the game interesting after few hours of playtime, which is why I chose to view it as a main part of the game.

To put it in a nutshell, the game can be really fun to play and has a lot of potential, but it still lacks in content and some proper endgame mechanics. Whether those are achieved by improving the endless mode or by adding another way to keep endgame interesting is yet to be seen. Eventhough, I focused a lot on aspects that still need improvement in the section above, I still recommend this game because I had a lot of fun playing it. It is still in early access, so most of the things I criticised will probably be fixed over time (or at least I hope so)

In the same time, your ability to actually finish a stage fast is heavily dictated by RNG, you need to travel the whole map to scavange loot bags that *might* have the fuel you need to finish the level and might not, and after that you need to run back to the bus.

My review was pretty short and may be conveying the wrong message, so to clarify:
My main criticism here is the lack of mechanical variety and player engagement, not the literal amount of updates the team pushed out. 

While appreciated, I'm not interested in cosmetic updates like the ability to swing on a swing set, splash screens, and popup notifications. Nor am I talking about basic functionality like run persistency, crit chance, or bullet settings. Using your list as an example, I'm interested in talking about the titan block event, the armored enemies, and items like the radar.

The titan block event is technically variety, in that it's an alternative to the highway blockage event, but I think its addition is overall a detriment to the game. The highway blockage requires the player to sit and protect a specific spot - which is different than their usual activities of constantly running around the map scrounging for loot and kiting enemies. I like this! The Titan block event, however, involves the player kiting enemies ( literally the same enemies they normally fight, just scaled up ) until they die, which is what the player is always doing. I don't like this, because now the Titan block event dilutes the pool for unique gameplay experiences, in favor of making me do more of the same thing I've BEEN doing. Technically, adding the Titan block event created variety in block events, but it REDUCED mechanical variety.

The game has a LOT of potential. I would give this a neutral if i could so i'm forced to make it a negative one because there's stuff to fix here.

The balance feels bad, overall winning a standard run is not too difficult if you know what you're doing but you never really get to feel powerful. For a game that takes inspiration in backpack battles/hero there's really not a lot of backpacking to do. In backpack battles you can have as many weapons as you can fit and then improve them with other items but here, due to the hand limitation more often than not you'll simply have to ignore a good chunk of things because you can't simply fit them so they mark your weapon of choice. 

There is a roboarm item that helps with that but being an S shaped legendary item it's rare and not easy to fit, plus then you will have the issue of finding and fitting stuff to take advantadge of the roboarm BUT, since this will be late into the run chances are low that you'll get to that. 

Endless is a thing, and it doesn't affect your win on a run, but the jump from day 7 (day 8 is the final boss) to day 9 is so massive that even my strongest builds can't make a dent on the hordes and it's simply not fun...which sucks because that's where you would be able to actually exploit the limits of building in the game (and things like the roboarm). This is potentially due to ranged weapons having a reload time that will simply give time for the horde to respawn and group up around you so there is a massive reliance on anything that lets you hit multiple targets (like the drill, which makes bullets go through enemies). I imagine melee builds can be more successful but i haven't tried them yet since i prefer ranged combat in survivors games. It is irrelevant to the case tho, because if an entire archetype feels bad...that's something that should 100% be fixed. 

Another big issue with the game is optimization. Optimization in survivors games can be tricky, as the massive amount of calculations, enemies, projectiles and items on the floor all take a toll on performance (Soulstone survivors devs had to basically remake the game to offer a better performance) but it is something necessary. Of course in an endless run eventually you'll have a problem but, if a regular AK firing 2 explosive projectiles multiple times per second whilst applying poison (a pretty basic thing is just basically ak+fork+fireworks+snake/rat) is already making the framerate drop insanely...we have a problem.  Specially when the graphics are pixel art(no complains there, the art is fantastic) which is not performance-intensive. 

Anyway, i'm eager to see what the devs cook, the potential of this game is amazing but it clearly needs time.

This game has 3 major flaws that makes it inferior to the rest of the genre:
1. The core loop is frustrating and just conflicts with the fantasy:
You want to get more loot to get stronger and kill more zombies, but the clock is against you, the game pushes you to finish stages fast (passing on loot) or the enemies will get so strong you can't finish the run.
So the game wants you to rush, but that means you get less cool loot, but that's the only way to win the run.
Even the level up mechanic (summons an air drop that gives you the only ability to get stronger mid-run) encourages you to let the clock tick in order to get something cool.

In the same time, your ability to actually finish a stage fast is heavily dictated by RNG, you need to travel the whole map to scavange loot bags that *might* have the fuel you need to finish the level and might not, and after that you need to run back to the bus.

This whole loop just feels unfun.

2. The runs start way too slow where you can only hold 1-2 weapons for a long long time until you get additional weapon slots, It takes a long time until you feel something interesting or powerful is going on, and even that is very limited by the next point:

3. Items are boring, build varieity is pretty much non-existent, all builds are played the same, all weapons feel the same, visually everything is the same.
unlike other backpack games, you rarely get hard decisions of what to keep and what to throw since most items are just unusable or only synergise with specific stuff.

Maybe they can fix these stuff, but as long as any of these points stay valid, there are other games in the genere that do it much better
